children.value: Robert Venturi and his wife Denise Brown, aghast with the architectural tendencies of their day, fought against the idea that the architect knew better than the people on what a building or a city should be
. One of the most notable examples of their ideology is expressed in their publication
. The book poses a bold indictment of Modernism by exploring the rampant success of the Las Vegas strip as a tourist destination, despite its anti-modernist architectural language[[2]].
One of the most famous findings from Venturi’s and Scott’s

is their comparison of buildings between the duck and the decorated shed. Venturi described “duck” buildings as “buildings that explicitly represent their function through their shape and construction”. The “decorated sheds” he described as “generic structures with added signs and decor that denote their purpose”, such as a Las Vegas casino with a flashy façade but general cookie cutter boxed interior. In general, the “duck” is representative of many modernist architectural pieces and works today where the form is expressive of function and volume. The “decorated shed” Brown and Venturi found prevalent in Las Vegas, where from the exterior the architects and developers do everything they can to draw you in, but once you’re inside the architecture becomes altogether regular. This is usually accomplished by large signs indicating function, or glamorous and ornamental facades.

properties.style: position: relative; display: block; margins: 0 20px 0 20px; max-width: 708px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;

children.value: Decorated sheds are common in these commercially successful tourist destination spots such as Las Vegas, Disney World, or Cancun where the imagery of the location is directly tied to the experience of it. Driving down the strip in Las Vegas the place seems bigger than life, largely because it

on the exterior. When you go inside however, you realize the architecture to be altogether regular, which is the primary downfall of the decorated shed. It sets the visitor up for disappointment, with more interest on the outside than the in.

One of the places that beautifully reinvents this idea of a decorated shed and the problems that come alongside it is the Royal Mile in Edinburgh. Forming a similar “strip-like” character to Las Vegas, everything a tourist is looking for emanates from that central street. The Royal Mile began as an open-air trading market in the 1100’s, and currently serves as a commercial district. The buildings along this road were made over a range of periods starting from the 12th century to modern day. Due to this rich cultural history, the buildings that occur along this mile follow the vernacular of the historical space and its unique architectural persona of medieval tenements and cobbled streets. This culturally rich center creates a strong sense of space that houses vibrant everyday activity. As one walks down the mile, the buildings all fit well together in context, even the sparse modern insertions along the way, and one can sense the spatial intelligence of the area over generations

However, this spatial intelligence, while providing a beautiful exterior, makes each building contiguous to the other. One has difficulty in telling the difference between a barbershop and a pub, with the only ornamentation difference being a small sign above the door.

children.value: I became lost many times on my nighttime expeditions, because the buildings gave very little guidance of what they were.

properties.style: position: relative; display: block; margins: 0 20px 0 20px; max-width: 455px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;

padding-bottom: 150.7692307692308%; position: relative; bottom: 0; left: 0; background-image: url('data:image/png;base64,'); background-size: cover; display: block;

children.value: The buildings on the Royal Mile are decorated sheds that are decorated something entirely different on the inside as it befits the times. One may walk the quiet streets, enter a seemingly dark rusticated stone structure, and suddenly enter into a world of neon signs, electronic music, and people chatting at a bar. In this way, the buildings are inversions of Venturi’s decorated shed of the “box” as interior with flashy exteriors. Rather than tear down buildings and build new ones every ten years like Las Vegas does to keep up with trends, Edinburgh is able to keep its history and context but insert a modernity to spaces from the inside out, that allows surprises for both the newcomer and resident alike at every turn. Walking inside a gothic style church one may quickly be affronted with glass interior doors and cubicle spaces for a real estate agency. The liminality of the space, being betwixt and between contexts, surprises the visitor. The Royal Mile is full of these little surprises. It’s what makes the space successful as a tourist location, as it is able to adapt to modern times through contextually inappropriate methods that still pay respect to the culture from the exterior. It is spatially intelligent on the exterior, and spatially unintelligent on the interior[[4].
Trufelman, Avery. "Lessons from Las Vegas." 99% Invisible - Interview with Denise Scott Brown. April 9, 2018. Accessed April 24, 2018.
Venturi, Robert, Denise Scott Brown, and Steven Izenour.
Blaikie, Gerarld The History of the Royal Mile. Edinburgh Sites.
Analysis of the Royal Mile from my four-day study period of Edinburgh during March, 2018.
